steps.title: “Copium” is another way to tell someone that they’re lying to themselves.
steps.content: “Copium” is another way to tell someone that they’re lying to themselves. In other words, it means that someone is in denial about something, or that they’re choosing to believe something that isn’t true. It’s often said to people who try to make excuses for a failure or who try to spin something that’s decidedly negative into a positive. [1] X Research source Person 1: “I didn’t trip, I was just trying a new dance move.” Person 2: “Dude. Copium.”

steps.title: The term is a combination of “cope” and “opium.”
steps.content: The term is a combination of “cope” and “opium.” In online contexts, like on Twitch or Twitter, people say “cope” to gloat over someone else’s social, political, or even gaming-related failure. When combined with “opium,” the term suggests that the target is depending on a sort of “coping drug” or opiate to get them through their snafu. [2] X Research source Person 1: “Sure, we lost the game, but we played hard and learned a lot!” Person 2: “Looks to me like you’re on the copium.”

steps.title: “Copium” was popularized on 4chan in an image of Pepe the Frog.
steps.content: “Copium” was popularized on 4chan in an image of Pepe the Frog. 4chan is a controversial message board responsible for minting a number of memes. In 2019, a 4chan user posted an image of the character Pepe the Frog (a prolific meme character) hooked to a ventilator labeled “COPIUM.” The image soon became a popular reaction image on the site. [3] X Research source In 2003, the rapper Keak da Sneak released an album titled Copium. Though it didn’t popularize the term, Mr. da Sneak did use it first, as far as anyone can tell. The term also appeared sparsely on 4chan around 2018, though it wasn’t widely used.

steps.title: “Copium” was further popularized in the 2020 presidential election.
steps.content: “Copium” was further popularized in the 2020 presidential election. As election results were tallied and it became apparent that Joe Biden would win the presidential race, 4chan, Twitter, and other social network users posted the Pepe Copium image to taunt Trump supporters. Often, the meme was altered to depict Pepe wearing a red “MAGA” hat. [4] X Research source

steps.title: The term then spread to the internet at large, particularly eSports.
steps.content: The term then spread to the internet at large, particularly eSports. Fans of competitive video games were quick to adopt the term. Most commonly, they use it as an incendiary taunt toward fans of a losing or struggling team, to suggest those fans are foolish for supporting the team. [5] X Research source Fans of video game streamers also use the term in stream chats to taunt a streamer who’s doing poorly in a game. Person 1: “They’re just having a bad season, but they’ll bounce back.” Person 2: “Lol. Copium.”

steps.title: Use “copium” to give someone a cheeky reality check online or via text.
steps.content: Use “copium” to give someone a cheeky reality check online or via text. Is a friend making a few too many excuses? Or maybe another online user just refuses to see things as they are. Hit them with a quick “copium” to let them know exactly what you think of their stance. [6] X Research source Them: “Oh come on, the movie wasn’t that bad. I thought it had good parts.” You: “That’s a whole lot of copium you got there."

steps.title: Use the copium emote on Twitch to gloat to other users.
steps.content: Use the copium emote on Twitch to gloat to other users. If your favorite eSports team just secured a dramatic victory, or your favorite streamer keeps losing to the same enemy, type out a quick “:copium:” to smugly poke fun at the losing team or the poor, persistent streamer. [7] X Research source Them: “You guys won this time, but that was just a fluke.” You: “:copium:”

steps.title: Hopium
steps.content: Hopium Similar to “copium,” but more specifically used when someone has irrational or even unhealthy amounts of optimism about something. [8] X Research source Person 1: “I don’t need to study. I’m gonna ace this test no problem.” Person 2: “I don’t think hopium is enough to pass this class, bud.”

steps.title: Seethe
steps.content: Seethe Often used in tandem with “cope,” “seethe” is a slightly more pointed term used to encourage another person’s anger about something. It’s often used in a smug or self-righteous tone. [9] X Research source Person 1: “Why didn’t you let me cheat off your test? You’re so rude.” Person 2: “Seethe about it.”

steps.title: Sadge
steps.content: Sadge Sadge is a variation of Pepe the Frog used to express sadness or disappointment, much like an emoticon. [10] X Research source Person 1: “Yeah, I definitely didn’t pass that test.” Person 2: “Sadge.”

steps.title: MonkaS
steps.content: MonkaS This is a Twitch emote that depicts Pepe the Frog visibly sweating with anxiety. It’s often used to express nervousness or concern. Person 1: “Wait, how do we already have another test tomorrow?” Person 2: “MonkaS.”
